segments.text: Gordon Volkman was one of these people.
We were interested in the fact that reflectivity from the bottom is going to be disturbed by the shape of the bottom.
And it became apparent that
If the bottom was sloped, the reflections from the bottom would appear to come in from a different direction.
Also, if one was looking down the ridge of a mountain range, one would be in a shadow zone for bottom reflected sound.
If one was looking down a valley, one would be in a sound channel from the standpoint of reflected sound.

simple result of this kind of thinking, which wasn't really very fundamental thinking, but it was important to start thinking this way, was that every spot on the ocean has its own directivity index for bottom reflected sound, so that both the intensities and directions could change a great deal upon the bottom configuration.

Also, another aspect of underwater sound, in which a great deal of field work was done, both with the standpoint of research work and also with the possibility of working with aviators, was that it quickly appeared one

one night that if the source was at the bottom, near the bottom of the ocean, in fact, if it was at a depth in which, if the water was deep and it was at a depth at which the sound velocity equaled the velocity near the surface, that about 20 miles, 15 to 20 miles away, there would be a very strong convergence zone.
And what was at least as important was that at all ranges out to that range, near-surface targets would be in the direct path.
So this was called the Reliable Acoustic Path.
Actually, it was the Naval Research Laboratory people who gave it that name and did some excellent work on it.
But this was sort of a new concept in our game.
It opened up the possibility of having much deeper towed sonar.
It had the possibility of instrumentation, bottom mounted instrumentation, in which we could listen to it.
If we were in deep water, we could listen to it out to a range of 20 miles.
out to a range of 10 miles, it would get weaker and weaker, and then it would start getting stronger and stronger.
So this opened up the range of things that could be done acoustically in the ocean a great deal.
It was another step in showing that if one was willing to be more special purpose in the way one utilized acoustics,
then the ocean was a more benign place than was usually given credit for.
Let's shut it off a minute.
Next, I would like to talk a little bit more about the research ships and submersibles.
As mentioned earlier, transportation is
an extremely important part of oceanography.
And even after you get there, if the equipment isn't good enough so that you can operate, you sort of lost the purpose, lost the advantage of being where you are.
There were two tacks on this.
I decided this was important enough to spend a good deal of time on it.
my bosses, both Hersey and Islin, and during much of this time, Admiral Smith was director.
I started spending more time on it in two veins.
One, a group of oceanographers, primarily under the sponsorship of ONR and with their well wishes, etc., we set about to...
try and get some new ships designed.
This went on over a good many years, but it ended up in the Agor class, about 180-foot ships, of which the Conrad was the first, and which Lamont received that ship.
And this gave them a dual ship capability, because they had the Vima and the Conrad.
The Conrad had all sorts of problems in the beginning.
The Lamont wanted to operate it themselves rather than running a chance of a Union crew.
There was a gas turbine on auxiliary power, which was a little bit too new to be very reliable.
A good deal of discussion is whether it was incompetence on the part of the user or incompetence on the part of the builder or incompetence on the part of the specs.
But finally the ship got out of the shipyard, and Lamont got it home and put it to work and altered some of the equipment, and it has been a very fine ship since.
Along parallel with this,
program of getting new ships was getting some ships to keep going in the game.

At this stage, I want to pay particular homage to Commander Charlie Bishop, who was in ONR, in the Undersea Warfare Section, who did a marvelous job, as a fellow named Bill Groverman had done before him,
Both of these people had a civilian compatriot called J.W.
Smith, or James Smith, who was one of the better organizers and in a quiet way was one of the visionary people in oceanography.
I think plate tectonics and a great many things in oceanography have much to be said for these people because they made it possible for American oceanography to go global.
in a large-scale sense.
At this time, Frosch had become director at Hudson Laboratories.
And in my own case, I set out to try and find what ships that were in the reserve fleets would be available.
We or I, I was doing most of the legwork.
Checking was a great many people, both within the Navy, Maritime Administration, and amongst the laboratories.
We settled down to about four ships, one of which was the Army FS class, about 180 footer, which subsequently, these were obtained by University of Rhode Island.
by Scripps, by the University of Oregon, and several other organizations got these as research ships.
At Woods Hole, we felt one of those would make an excellent replacement for the Atlantis, but it was not capable enough to take on the kind of work that some of us visualized ought to be done.
The Navy fleet tug, which was about 200 feet long, had to do about 14 knots and was big and tough, was also a fine ship and available in supply.
But the working spaces on it would have required a great deal of conversion in order to make them so it had a logical layout for our work.
Also, it was a single screw ship, and we felt for maneuverability purposes we should have it.

The Maritime Administration had a V-4 tug, which looked very good, but there was very little high seas work in which we could find people who had operated them enough to know how good seaboats they were.
So we really settled on the
on the Navy's salvage ships, the ARSs.
Actually, the decision on my own part was made on New Year's Eve of 1956 or 57.
And after looking at some other ships, I stopped off in Norfolk to take another look at this ARS class and to
All the boys out in the salvage department of the Navy were having a New Year's party, and obviously they felt their ship was the best.
And having ridden on nearly all of these ships myself, I couldn't help but agree with them.
And even though it was more complicated than we wanted and so big it kind of frightened us, we decided that was the ship to lay our money on.
The primary criteria some of us kept asking ourselves was if you
had a job of operating off Iceland or circling it in the wintertime, which of these ships would you choose?
This appeared to be the toughest, best-riding ship that was available in the reserve fleet in a size that was small enough so that our bosses would consider taking it.
This was extremely important because none of the oceanographic institutions wanted to take, the private labs wanted to take on a ship that was
too big.
Well, anyhow, J.W.

Smith and Charlie Bishop in O&R risked about 30% of their next year's budget, which they hadn't received yet and committed it, on getting the Argo for Scripps, the chain for Woods Hole, and a still bigger AVP ship for Bob Frosh at Hudson Laboratories.
of particular interest here and to show the versatility of the Navy group.

Woods Hole, Island would not accept a ship of this size, so the Navy made the, at our request, at our unofficial request, made the conversion, crewed it for one year at the end of which time Woods Hole could either take it over themselves or have the
MSTS crew continue.
Scripps, on the other hand, Revell wanted to have nothing to do with the Navy in any part of it.
He just wanted enough money to have every aspect of the conversion handled by Scripps and to have a Scripps crew.
Bob Frosch at Hudson Laboratories took exactly the opposite view there.
He wanted to have their laboratory have no responsibility, really, for the conversion or for the operation of the ship.
And ONR and their people saw to it that all three requirements were met.
This was a piece of administrative flexibility which is seldom seen, but it was certainly appreciated.

These ships were, as I'd said before, the ones that really permitted the ocean-wide cruises with large enough groups of people and enough equipment to pretty much take on whatever problem one wanted to take on.
We were very fortunate in the

Office of Naval Research, that Charlie Bishop, who was a submarine man, was followed by Commander Swede Momsen, who was also a submarine man, and felt that submersibles made good sense for science and good sense for the Navy to be involved with.
Not many people in oceanography seem to feel that submersibles made very good sense.
The Navy's work with Trieste was such that some marine biology and a tiny little bit of physical oceanography had been done out of San Diego.
But they were not really, in any sense of the word, were they workhorses of oceanography.
Cousteau, with his submersible, with his ship Calypso and his submersible Surcouf, had devised a submersible which was easy to use, was rationally designed to be operated with the
surface ship that he had.
And this submarine was used in a variety of research to show some of its potential.
And the Westinghouse Electric Company also got a submersible, had Casteau build a submersible Deep Star for them, which was rented and used.
In my own thinking, belay that.

The Office of Native Research started a deep submersible program for the combined use of how deep should military submarines go to, and how can you learn more about the background for such things as that.
and more particular for the factors involved in making submersibles go deeper for any purpose whatsoever.
In this vein, they sponsored work at the model basin.
And Ed Wink was a very important person here.
He had been a mechanical engineer at the model basin.
working in submarines.
He then went down to Southwest Research Institute.
ONR sponsored research work there on factors having to do with deep submersibles and hull design.
Ed got in touch with Lewis Reynolds, the Reynolds Metals Company, who had been a, as a,
very young man or boy had met Simon Lake and was convinced that submarines had a future.
After he grew up and became one of the top administrators in the Reynolds Metals Company, he had the finances to do something about it.
So while a few oceanographers were concerned with how one operates at depth,
The ONR was putting some money into this game, perhaps a quarter of a million dollars a year in one way or another, perhaps double that in some aspects.
Ed Wink hit the jackpot with Lewis Reynolds, and preliminary work was proceeding on the design of Illuminati.
I had been one of those people who felt the submersible had a future.
Hadn't worried too much about the exact details of it, except that because the ocean is up to six miles deep, you want to build it to go as deep as is practical.
But if it wasn't going to be consistently usable,
Then it had no chance of selling.
So what we tried to do was to find a critical group of scientists, engineers, financiers that thought that it made a good sense.
Then get an idea of the state of the art and the amount of money that might be available and see about how much of a submersible it was practical to start out with.
The ONR had a
had a meeting on deep water work in 56, in which this received a good deal of discussion.
And actually, it was Bill Bascom who called attention to the fact that, along with all the loud talk, if we really had anything to say, we should
end up so that the assembled group had a specific recommendation to give to the science world as a whole, the Navy in particular.
So the part that Bill Bascom played in getting a specific recommendation going that the United States should have a deep submersible capability was very important.
That report
That meeting, incidentally, was written up as the National Academy of Sciences special publication.
Although the design work of the new submersible, which turned out to be called Illuminat, was being done at Southwest Research Institute under the direction of Ed Wink and under the sponsorship of
Lewis Reynolds at Reynolds Metals Company.
Fred Spees from Scripps and myself were asked to serve on the design committee as oceanographers to see to it that it was compatible with the needs of oceanography.
Those were very interesting times.
The fundamentals of designing a deep submersible were pretty clear.
It was largely a question of
what kind of materials, metals, sizes, and so forth were consistent with the sort of a budget that had better be in the low millions.
For myself, I never really worried.
On a philosophical point of view, I never worried about the money, because the world was operating about
40 research ships, 30 or 40 research ships, of which the U.S. was running about half.
All of these would be more expensive than the submersible, and most oceanographers would gladly welcome another research ship, which could only improve the overall global capability by 3%.
And it seemed logical that rather than building another general-purpose research ship,
it would make more sense to build some special purpose ships that could go down to the bottom and look with the eyeball.
And in actuality, these are really perhaps more comparable to the fact that the geologist has long been associated with the burrow or the mule.
And we wanted some kind of a mule that would dive so we could go down and look over the terrain that was otherwise not accessible.
The general plan behind the Illuminaut was that Reynolds would pay for it and sponsor it.
The electric boat company would build it and do the detailed designs.
UNR, through the hand and eye of their assistant, the Woods Hole Oceanographic Assistant, the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, would rent it and operate it for science.
And then at some future date, it would be decided that the submarine was paid for through rental and it would belong to the Navy or to the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution.

It turned out that for a variety of reasons, many of which were very legitimate and others probably seemed a little fuzzier, the questions of operational control and what good business were and were not good business practices, neither Woods Hole and Reynolds were not able to arrive at a common document which would permit this to happen.
Woods Hole, here at Woods Hole, we had been working under the general assumption this would happen, might happen or would happen.
We had begun to hire crew for the Illuminat.
ONR had started giving us half a million dollars a year to prepare for this event and to hire crew to start buying instrumentation and getting ready.

At this stage of the game, I want to mention that the pilot we hired, or that I had hired, was Bill, had looked up and found, was Bill Rainey, who was one of the heroes of the small submersible business, who was really the operating, he was the chief pilot and the one most responsible for it for many years.

along about this time it was decided here at Woods Hole that the ship the submersible program would be in the under the general cognizance of Earl Hayes who was in the Department of Ocean Engineering and at
At that time, I remained heavily involved with it, but more in an advisory capacity than in a line capacity.
When it became apparent that the submersible aluminate was not going to come here, we worked with
Harold Froelich from the electronics section of General Mills, who had been proposing that they build a small submersible called the CPOP.
We utilized his version of that submarine, which was a very elementary, undersized submarine.
Elvin that here was something we could buy off the shelf.
We wouldn't need to rebuild and design a new submarine.
And this was used as the administrative logic of why we should use the O and R money we already had and were getting to go ahead with a submersible program at Woods Hole.
This
scheme worked, and Woods Hole ended up with a submersible.
We wrote up a set of specifications.
We wrote up a set of specifications to alter the CPAP so it would meet what we considered our requirements.
This turned out to be a good deal more of a submarine than CPOP was.
And the price jumped from $250,000 up to $600,000 or $700,000.
Then because the Navy wanted to experiment with a Navy-type steel, it was decided to build it out of a Navy-type steel rather than a commercial-type steel.
This raised the price about $150,000, I think, or some such thing as this, because it involved a much more comprehensive test procedure.
Now, one of the very important things in the submersible program was that many people were involved.
In fact, people from many countries.
was involved, not so much in an official capacity.
But unofficially, everyone who had a submarine, who wanted to build a submarine, operated pretty much together, kept checking notes.
We came to pretty much the same kinds of meetings to find out how things were going.
It was clear there wasn't enough money for everybody to do everything.

So what they tried to do was compare notes on operations, notes on safety, to talk to other people in the business so you could go home and tell your bosses that if you didn't hurry, you'd be left behind.
And this was strictly a very favorable, pleasant, international system of everybody raising themselves with the bootstraps.
This submersible becomes the albin.
When do you start experimenting on the width of the hull of the albin?
Is this when you begin to decide how thick the hull should be?
The work on how thick the hull should be is
In one sense, it's very complicated.
In another sense, it is very elementary.

From simple geometry, you can figure out what the forces are, because if you build a submarine only to go shallow, it is so thin that it is able to collapse in any number of funny modes, and you need complicated ribs.
And this is a real job for the mathematical experts.
However, if you decide to build a whole of a simple form,
like a cylinder or even more so a sphere.
And then you design it to go deep.
The hole gets thick enough so it is what we call a simple, it would fail in pretty close to the pressure of simple collapse.
And you would not have the thing going out of round and getting into mathematical complications.
until you got almost to the ultimate point.
So from this standpoint, the deeper the submarine goes, the easier it is to design.
You choose the material on the basis of corrosion, on the basis of its strength-weight ratio, and on the basis of its cost, and on the basis of whether
You can weld it, form it, and so forth.
